scene.name: gamers-one
scene.line: `(CONWAY clears his throat.)`
scene.option: Have y'all seen a breaker box down here?
Oh, sorry, didn't know there was anyone down here.

scene.name: gamers-one-b
scene.line: `(To BOB.)` Did you hear something?
`(To EMILY.)` Uh, no. Sorry, I was looking at the rules again.
`(To BOB.)` It gets easier as you go. Look, you said you rolled a "five," right? That means you get to pick up your marker and move it anywhere on the map.
`(To BEN.)` So it's your turn now, right?
`(To BOB.)` Oh, yeah I guess so. Where'd you put that twenty-sided die?
I don't see it. Did you drop it?
Uh ... It should be easy enough to find. It glows in the dark.

scene.name: gamers-two
scene.line: `(CONWAY clears his throat, but gets no response from the people at the table.)`
scene.option: I just need to get by you for a minute.

scene.name: gamers-two-b
scene.line: `(To EMILY.)` I think it rolled down off to the left there, but I don't see it.
Well, I'm not going to go looking for it. It's too dark down there.
One of you go down and get it, and I'll just ... study the rules here.

scene.name: gamers-three
scene.line: `(CONWAY taps his foot, but gets no response from the people at the table.)`
scene.option: If I can hit that breaker box I can get the lights back on.
What kind of game is that?

scene.name: gamers-three-b
scene.line: `(To EMILY.)` I think you were right about the instant crisis rolls. There's a whole separate table of them in the back.
I don't like that rule anyway; it's not fun, it's just random and frustrating.
`(To BOB.)` The randomness is what makes it realistic, Bob.

scene.name: gamers-four
scene.line: `(CONWAY clears his throat, but gets no response from the people at the table.)`
scene.option: I really need to get the power back on and make this delivery.
You seem pretty focused on that game.

scene.name: gamers-four-b
scene.line: `(To BEN.)` I still don't understand how you win.

`(Reading aloud.)` Roll the twenty-sided die once for each player, and refer to "Appendix C: Table of Psychogeographical Anxiety/Address Correlations." Locate the resulting street addresses on the roadmap and move each player marker to the appropriate location.
That doesn't help.
I don't think you `can` win. It says on the box it's a tragedy.

scene.name: gamers-five
scene.line: `(CONWAY crosses his arms.)`
scene.option: You're not going to let me by, are you?
You said you're missing a piece?

scene.name: gamers-five-b
scene.line: `(To BEN.)` OK, so just to get started we need that twenty-sided die.

Yeah that gets us on the road. Well, hopefully: if you roll a "one," you drive into a ditch. If you roll a "two" or a "nine" or a "twelve," you have to write down a new anxiety and roll again. If you roll a "five," you get to move your piece anywhere on the map you want.
Bob, go get that die.
It's too dark down there.
`(To BOB.)` Well that should make it easy, the damn thing glows in the dark!

scene.name: gamers-last
scene.line: `(CONWAY knocks on the table, but gets no response from the people at the table.)`
scene.option: If you could just move your chairs a bit, I can scoot right by.

scene.name: gamers-last-b
scene.line: `(EMILY, BEN and BOB argue about the rules of their game and who should be responsible for retrieving their lost game piece, a glow-in-the-dark twenty-sided die.)`
